article.title: Mammalian and Invertebrate Models as Complementary Tools for Gaining Mechanistic Insight on Muscle Responses to Spaceflight

funding.text: NI Department for the Economy (DfE) Research Studentship
Horizon Centre for Doctoral Training at the University of Nottingham (UKRI grant no. EP/S023305/1)
Spanish Plan Estatal de Investigación Científica y Desarrollo Tecnológico Grant RTI2018-099309-B-I00

article.abstract: Bioinformatics approaches have proven useful in understanding biological responses to spaceflight. Spaceflight experiments remain resource intensive and rare. One outstanding issue is how to maximize scientific output from a limited number of omics datasets from traditional animal models including nematodes, fruitfly, and rodents. The utility of omics data from invertebrate models in anticipating mammalian responses to spaceflight has not been fully explored.

sections.introduction: Exposure to the unique set of spaceflight environmental conditions, including microgravity, cosmic radiation, isolation, and confinement, has been shown to induce significant physiological changes in all studied species to date [1,2,3]. These physiological responses, such as skeletal muscle atrophy, can negatively impact the health of astronauts and may also compromise mission success if left unabated [4].
sections.methods: Table 1 lists the various datasets used in this study. These datasets can be found in NASA GeneLab and are cited in these references [24,25,37,38,39,40,41].
sections.results: Table 1 shows the transcriptomic datasets used in this study. These datasets included RNA-seq and microarray datasets. Model organisms represented are mouse, fruitfly, and nematode.
sections.discussion: Skeletal muscles are highly adaptive to changes in mechanical forces and display a robust regenerative capacity.

experimental_factors.tissue: soleus, extensor digitorum longus, gastrocnemius, quadriceps, vastus lateralis
experimental_factors.tissue_raw: soleus, extensor digitorum longus, gastrocnemius, quadriceps, vastus lateralis

article.insights_summary: This study aimed to determine the effects of spaceflight on the transcriptome of distinct mammalian muscle types and to define shared transcriptomic signatures across a variety of model organisms.
article.acknowledgments: GeneLab data are courtesy of the NASA GeneLab Data Repository [158].
